they always have two things in common no

user no matter what and secondly you

website 101 now static websites are
exactly what they sound like if you're
not already familiar with them it's just
the same exact process except there's no
code involved so on a static website all
of those assets the HTML CSS all that
stuff is already going to be
pre-rendered sitting on a web server so
as soon as a request comes in to access
the data the data will just be
immediately sent back like a file
straight to the browser makes sense
right now the reason people really like
static websites including me is that a
they're super fast so in the web
performance world there's this metric
that we really care about which is time
to first byte so how long does it take
for your website to start sending that
response back to a user and when you're
running code on the back end to process
a request you're always going to have
some added latency because you're always
gonna be running a process you know
executing CPU cycles requiring memory
and stuff like that and it's not the
same thing with a static site
secondarily they're really easy to

for example dub-dub-dub phu kham the

then finally to actually deploy your

what you need to do is you basically

where cloud front comes into play
so cloud front is Amazon CDN and what it
allows you to do is basically cache
copies of your website in all the
different AWS regions and availability
zones all around the world and that way
if a user visits your website and
they're located in Sydney for example
they're going to view a cached copy of
your website from the Sydney region and
that is going to make your website much
faster to people externally so the
reason you want to do that is because
again it's super fast it's also super
inexpensive same as before the tooling
is also great it's very flexible there's
tons of great options in there it's
reliable so if cloud front goes down you
can guarantee that almost the rest of
the web is down as well and finally the
tooling again is super super awesome
now the way you set up CloudFront is
slightly more complicated than s3 so
I'll just walk you through it real quick
so if I go to the Amazon console and
switch over to cloud France then what
you're going to want to do is create
what's called a CloudFront distribution
so you can click create distribution
click on the web option there cuz you
want to do this for a website and the
first thing you need to do is tell it
what what website you want to cache
files from now in our case you actually
want to cache it from the s3 website
that you already built so I'm just gonna
paste the s3 URL in here and I'm just

this field should only contain the
domain info none of the HTTP colon slash
last stuff
the next thing you want to do is set up
an SSL policy so you should always be
running your websites over HTTPS so I
like to enable this option which
basically says redirect all HTTP traffic
to HTTPS finally you want to Gert
almost finally you want to go to the
object caching option here which
basically specifies how long cloud
furniture is going to cache your web
pages for now this is where most people
screw things up right because when
you're caching a site and you want to be
superfast
the idea is you always want to serve
your website from the cache you never
want it to not be cached and so what you
should do is come in here copy this
maximum TTL value which is the maximum
amount of time CloudFront will allow you
to cache the page copy the value and
override the default and the minimum
values with this maximum value and there
again the reason you want to do this is
so that your pages will always be cached
for the maximum amount of time and then
finally if you really obsessed with web
performance you can come down here and
click compress objects automatically yes
and what this will do is if your your
static website is just consisting of
like HTML pages and images and stuff
like that
this will automatically handle things
like gzipping your pages to reduce the

speeding up the page load times and
stuff like that so finally you can click

you'll be good to go now if I actually

CDN so this is localized to where we are

services so this is the identifier
you're gonna need in a moment now what
happens if you have your site
distributed with conference but then you
want to make a change so let's say you
update your website you upload it to s3
and then you go view your website and
you realize the page didn't update right
well that's because the Cloud front is
now caching your what your web pages for
like a year and so you obviously don't
want to wait a year for that web page to
fall out in the cache before users can
see your update
so what you need to do is invalidate
your cache now the way you do that on
the command line is very simple so first
off you enable the preview of the cloud
front functionality in the CLI and then
secondarily you're gonna run the cloud
front create invalidation command and
you give it that distribution ID from
earlier and what this is going to do is
tell cloud front in a single command to
forget about all the pages on your site
and remove them from the cache and what
I like to do is every time I'm building
a site and I deploy a new update I just
immediately run this command in a script
and that way it just wipes the cache and
then the new version of the site can be
loaded make sense cool now if we
actually come back to our command line
we can run this as well and you'll get
some nice little output just like this
BAM and it's in progress so our
invalidation is now in progress whoops
in progress got there we go anyways back
to this so the one thing you need to
know about in validations is that they
take roughly 15 minutes to complete so
one of the trade-offs you need to think
about if you want to use cloud front to
make your site very performant is that
when you're releasing new updates to the
site there's always gonna be a roughly
fifteen to twenty minute like delay
